moon_data.title: Bluegrass Music News and Information
moon_data.subtitle: one of the first 60 websites, first music-based website
moon_data.text: A website dedicated to bluegrass music, lyrics, and chords. It changed its name to Banjo in 1992, and Cybergrass in 1995. The website remains available today, making it one of the longest standing websites (it is under construction as of October 2025).

moon_data.title: XCoffee / Trojan Room Coffee Pot
moon_data.subtitle: the first webcam
moon_data.text: A coffee pot at the Computer Laboratory of the University of Cambridge was live broadcasted to all desktop computers on the local office network, to save people working in the building the disappointment of finding the coffee machine empty. It became the first webcam when it was connected to the internet in 1993 and could be watched from anywhere.

moon_data.title: Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (SLAC)
moon_data.subtitle: the third website and first website served out of North America
moon_data.text: Paul Kunz from the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (SLAC) visited CERN in September 1991 and was enthralled by the Web. He brought the software back and worked with Stanford Librarian Louise Addis to create a website hosting its online database and digital catalogue of documents. This was the first web server outside of Europe and the first in North America.

moon_data.title: WorldWideWeb browser
moon_data.subtitle: the first browser and web page editor
moon_data.text: TBL built the world’s first browser at CERN. In 1993 its source code was released into the public domain. Then a year later, it was renamed Nexus Browser. In celebration of the 30th anniversary of the WorldWideWeb, a group of developers and designers convened at CERN in 2019 to rebuild the original browser within a contemporary browser (shown below).

moon_data.title: World Wide Web
moon_data.subtitle: the first website
moon_data.text: TBL created the first website at CERN. It was hosted on TBL’s NeXT computer and linked to relevant CERN documents. The World Wide Web differed from other hypertext systems available at the time. A key difference was that the Web allowed unidirectional links rather than bidirectional ones, so that someone could link to another resource without action being taken by the owner of that resource.

era_data.text:
Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1989 while working at CERN (the European Organization for Nuclear Research). He submitted Information Management: A Proposal to his managers, which he said would be based on 'a large hypertext database with typed links'. His breakthrough came when he married hypertext to the internet, developing three crucial elements to the Web: the uniform resource locator (URL); the publishing language Hypertext Markup Language (HTML); and the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP). TBL published a short summary of the World Wide Web project on the newsgroup, alt.hypertex, to explain its purpose and how it worked, and invite collaborators. He went on to develop the first web server and the first web browser, WorldWideWeb. CERN, with TBL’s urging, committed its source code to the public domain in 1993.

Through these creations, TBL had created a medium of global information that could be accessed worldwide by anyone connected to the Internet.

Note: The older websites on this timeline will not have been archived until 1996 or later. The versions displayed here are the earliest, working versions of the websites.

moon_data.title: Cyberia Café
moon_data.subtitle: the first Internet café
moon_data.text: The website of the first Internet café in the world. Cyberia opened its doors in London in September 1994 and though it was intended as a space for women to surf the Web, it was open to all. From there the idea caught on and cyber cafés opened up all over the world.

moon_data.title: PizzaNet
moon_data.subtitle: allegedly the first website to sell a physical product
moon_data.text: Pizza Hut announced a pilot program to take pizza orders in Santa Cruz, California through their new website, PizzaNet. In their press release, the company describes their killer app with detailed instructions on how to place the order. It details how to connect to the internet and use the website — and even shares the physical location of the central server, which was in Wichita, Kansas at the time. Many consider it to be the first website to sell a physical product, though that’s contested.

moon_data.title: GeoCities
moon_data.subtitle: a free website hosting service known for striking user-created websites
moon_data.text: In November 1994, David Bohnett and John Rezner created Beverly Hills Internet — which they soon after renamed GeoCities— to allow people to create and publish websites free of charge. For many, it gave people their first experience of coding a website and publishing content online. Its user-generated webpages were especially known to be colorful, expressive, and full of animated GIFs. In 1999, Yahoo! acquired Geocities when it was the third-most visited website on the internet. Geocities was shuttered in 2009 following failed attempts to monetize the service.

moon_data.title: eBay
moon_data.subtitle: one of the first online marketplace and auction websites
moon_data.text: Founded by Pierre Omidyar in September 1995 to make some extra cash. It was initially called AuctionWeb, and one of the first items he sold on the site was a broken laser pointer for $14.83. Surprised, Omidyar contacted the winning bidder to ask if he understood that the laser pointer was broken; the buyer explained: 'I'm a collector of broken laser pointers.' eBay still has 132 million yearly active buyers worldwide and handled $73 billion in transactions in 2023.

moon_data.title: Internet Archive
moon_data.subtitle: the Internet’s library hosting the largest archive of digital materials
moon_data.text: In May 1996, Brewster Kahle founded the Internet Archive, which operates the digital library, archive.org. The Wayback Machine was launched a few years later in 2001. The website gives free access to digitized media including archived websites, texts, images, videos, music, and software applications. It allows people to upload and download digital materials and archive websites (and explore them as we do on this very webpage). The Archive also works to preserve as much of the public web as possible using web crawlers to capture websites automatically. The Archive has been a pillar of the free and open internet movement, with a mission to provide 'universal access to all knowledge'.

era_data.text:
TBL moved from CERN to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1994 to found the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C), an international community devoted to developing open, interoperable web standards. These open standards — along with TBL’s commitment to keep the Web free and in the public domain — ensured that the Web’s format remained flexible and accessible. This led to it quickly proliferating around the world.

The general public’s use of the Web began to pick up in 1993. By mid-1994, there were 2,738 websites, and by the end of 1994, the Web had 10,000 servers and 10 million users.

Note: The older websites on this timeline will not have been archived until 1996 or later. The versions displayed here are the earliest, working versions of the websites.

moon_data.title: Twitter
moon_data.subtitle: a microblogging and social network service
moon_data.text:
Twitter’s website was launched in July 2006 by four founders, Jack Dorsey, Noah Glass, Biz Stone, and Evan Williams in San Francisco, California. The original code name for the project was twttr, inspired by the name of Flickr and the five character length of SMS short codes in the US. The name was changed to Twitter when they were able to purchase the domain, twitter.com, months later. A signature characteristic of the service was that posts, AKA tweets, were limited to 140 characters in length.

For most of its history, 10% of users authored 80-90% of tweets. Its popularity grew very quickly. When the platform was showcased at the 2007 South by Southwest conference, Twitter’s usage grew from an average 20,000 tweets per day to 60,000 over the course of a week.

moon_data.title: Etsy
moon_data.subtitle: an online commerce website focused on handmade and vintage goods
moon_data.text: The website was launched in 2005 by a small company called iospace. One of its three founders, Robert Kalin, said that the name Etsy was a nonsense word he chose to build the brand from scratch. He says he got the name from watching Federico Fellini’s 1963 film, 8 ½ and hearing the characters say /“etsi/”, meaning /“oh yes/” in Italian. The website initially gained traction by releasing tools to help sellers gain exposure and traffic, including keyword tags and even Adobe Flash-visualizations. By the end of 2024, Etsy had over 100 million items in its marketplace and connected 8 million sellers with 96 million buyers. That same year, Etsy had $12.6 billion USD total sales on its platform.

moon_data.title: YouTube
moon_data.subtitle: an online video sharing platform
moon_data.text: Three former employees of PayPal founded Youtube in February 2005. One of the founders, Jawed Karim, said that the inspiration for Youtube came from the Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show controversy in 2004 when Janet Jackson's breast was briefly exposed during the halftime show, and the fact that he could not easily find a video of the incident. YouTube’s other founders, Chad Hurley and Steve Chen, said that they originally envisioned it to be a video-based online dating site. To achieve this, they made craigslist ads looking for women to upload videos of themselves in exchange for $100. This plan was unsuccessful and they decided to turn it into a general video sharing service. By mid-2024, YouTube hosted approximately 14.8 billion videos in total. As of late 2025, it remains the second most visited site in the world.

moon_data.title: wikiHow
moon_data.subtitle: an online, collaboratively written how-to manual
moon_data.text: Founder Jack Herrick aspired to make wikiHow the'largest how-to guide for everything'. Inspired by Wikipedia’s editing model, Herrick forked Mediawiki (the open source software underlying Wikipedia) and modified it to be a how-to manual. He launched the site on January 15, 2005 — the fourth anniversary of the birth of Wikipedia, to 'honor their gift'. By 2009, the six-employee business was seeing 20 million monthly views. wikiHow’s articles follow a standard format: a descriptive step-by-step process, usually accompanied by an image — all of them authored and edited by thousands of its users.

moon_data.title: Flickr
moon_data.subtitle: an image and video hosting and social network platform
moon_data.text: A Vancouver-based company called Ludicorp founded Flickr in February 2004, which it built using tools it had originally created for a web-based massively multiplayer online (MMO) game it was developing. Originally it had a chat room called FlickrLive, but the feature was eventually dropped as the codebase moved away from its MMO origins. Flickr’s popular features include tagging, favoriting, and group albums. They also offer the option to use Creative Commons and public domain licenses — which can also be used to filter images when searching their collections.

era_data.text:
The years following the Dot-com bubble marked a new era with the proliferation of interactive and multimedia websites. Those centered around user-generated content exploded in popularity. Microsoft’s digital encyclopedia Encarta surrendered to volunteer-edited Wikipedia. Likewise social media sites like Myspace and Facebook; social news sites like Digg and Reddit; and media sharing sites like Flickr, Vimeo, and Youtube, all began to permeate the Web. You no longer had to know how to code or administer a website to meet or share with others online — you only had to log in.

Within the decade since the general public started to use the Web, the number of websites online had grown by 19,000x — from 2738 websites in 1994 to about 52 million websites in 2004.

moon_data.title: UN Digital Library
moon_data.subtitle: first UN Resolution on the protection of human rights on the Internet
moon_data.text: Recognizing that people were increasingly spending more time online, the United Nations adopted its first resolution on protecting peoples’ human rights on the internet, stating: “the same rights that people have offline must also be protected online.” It specifically focused on the right to free expression. As governments worldwide increasingly passed internet legislation that did not carefully consider public harms, there was a growing need to expand the scope of human rights protections online. The UN would go on to adopt four more such resolutions over the next nine years, expanding its scope to include the right to internet access and privacy online.

moon_data.title: HTML5
moon_data.subtitle: fifth and final HTML recommendation that is now a living open web standard
moon_data.text:
As the uses of the web evolved over time, the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) has adapted its technical standards to ensure compatibility and consistency of the display and interactivity of websites. The W3C’s recommendation for HTML5 in 2014 marked the dawn of the modern, application-capable web. It was the fifth and final major HTML version, which has continued as the specification known as the HTML Living Standard.
Among other things, HTML5 introduced <video> and <audio> elements for native multimedia and <canvas> for 2D graphics. This website, Hello World Wide Web, is made possible entirely by using the components that HTML5 allows. It uses two <canvas> elements overlaid on top of each other, one for the color changing gradients and one for rendering the timeline's SVG graphics.

moon_data.title: Ethereum
moon_data.subtitle: first blockchain platform to introduce and popularize smart contracts
moon_data.text:
Vitalik Buterin initially described a way to build decentralized applications using a blockchain in 2014. He argued in his original white paper, that the distributed ledger technology could be applied to other uses beyond digital currencies, such as for tracking real-world assets and online decentralized governance. Thus the vision for Ethereum was to offer a globally-shared computing platform that is secure, decentralized and permanently open for all.
Over time, Ethereum made it possible for developers to build Decentralized Applications (DApps) — software whose code or data no single party could control. DApps have made Ethereum the most widely used blockchain for disputed computing. Many call this type of blockchain-based, decentralized infrastructure, Web3. However, DApps and Web3 apps have limitations, preventing them from being as widely adopted as client/server-based web applications (which many people associate with Web 2.0). As of 2025, some of the primary constraints are that Web3 apps are not integrated into most modern browsers, and it usually takes additional knowledge, extra steps, and software to run them. Additionally, the blockchain transactions that DApps rely upon run slower as their computation relies on a more complex, decentralized network.

moon_data.title: InterPlanetary File System (IPFS)
moon_data.subtitle: peer-to-peer network and protocol for distributed file storage
moon_data.text:
Juan Benet published the IPFS white paper in 2014, describing a system of peer-to-peer distributed file sharing based on content addressing. As opposed to a location-based web protocol like HTTP/HTTPS, he proposed that IPFS would uniquely identify each file with a content ID. Benet founded Protocol Labs in May 2014 and with his team, launched IPFS in 2015.
Through IPFS, anyone on the network could publish and serve a file using the content address, and others could find and access the file from anyone else using a distributed hash table, which stores metadata and content location information. If a person retrieves content online and caches it locally, those files can be accessed offline — which can be helpful especially for those with limited or intermitted internet connectivity. In the decade since its launch, IPFS has been used to curb censorship of the web in Catalonia and Turkey.

moon_data.title: Melonland
moon_data.subtitle: new wave of expressive personal sites available through the distributed web
moon_data.text:
Paying homage toGeoCities, Kyle Drake created Neocities in 2013 to archive sites previously hosted on the lost service. It is now a commercial web hosting and content management service that allows people to create their own websites, offering 1 gigabyte of file storage and 200 gigabytes of bandwidth for free per user. Neocities took part in a protest stunt against the US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) in 2014 to protest the FCC’s stance against net neutrality by throttling its bandwidth speeds when IPs from the agency tried to access Neocities.
Notably, Neocities was the first major site to implement IPFS in 2015. The service hosted about 55,000 to 57,000 sites in 2015, and in 2025, Neocities reached over one million hosted sites.
The Neocities web page linked here, Melonland, was first published in 2016 and is an excellent example of a new generation of expressive personal websites that harkens back to the older generation of creative, GIF-full web pages.

era_data.text: By 2012, the World Wide Web had firmly established itself as an indispensable piece of open internet infrastructure for global human connection and knowledge. Meanwhile, governments, corporations, and other concentrated powers increasingly sought to censor and limit people’s access to the web when it undermined their interests. Governments also saw the potential of web services to be used for surveillance. They secured this fate by passing laws in the name of ‘cybersecurity’ and other rationales to make it easier for companies to disclose and share personal information with state agencies. In response to these and other threats on the web, there was a new concerted effort to build protocols and methods to further decentralize the web — and to make it impossible for any central authority to censor content, surveil people, or limit access. The most well-known and well-resourced of these efforts involved blockchain (AKA distributed ledger) technologies. At the same time, many other approaches to make the web more distributed, peer-to-peer, and local-first multiplied. Examples of peer-to-peer web protocols include InterPlanetary File System (IPFS), WebTorrent, and Dat — all of which were launched in this era.
